What should we do with the GET /servers/{server_id}/os-security-groups ? I think we can keep it as is. But I can also accept if somebody says to drop it with the same reasoning, as it is a proxy API to neutron.

yeah, that is proxy APIs but it is not dropped (dropped means for >=2.36 microversion and keep working for older microversion) in 2.36 where all other proxy APIs were.

What should we do with the POST /servers API? The POST /servers API allows specifying zero or more security group names when the server is created. And the response also has a security_groups field. 

I'm not sure we can remove the security_groups from the server create request as that would be a major functionality loss, if the server is created with networks specified (instead of ports). But then it would be make sense to keep it in the response too.

This creates an asymmetry. The POST req/rsp will have security_groups while the rest of the server manipulation APIs will not have. I would like to see opinion from others about this as we missed this fact during the PTG.

In any case, the matter of writing logs is left to ansible. VF just ensures that there is a place to put them in.

I think you make a confusion between logs and artifacts directory.
Logs directory is the place where the callback will write Ansible outputs from the validation playbook:
/var/log/validations/<uuid>.json

Artifacts directory is the place where Ansible will dump the stdout, stderr, rc, console, command, ansible.cfg.. :
/var/log/validations/artifacts/uuid/

If I understand correctly your change here, you want to address the "/var/log/validations" problematic, which could be non existent or wrong access rights.

The create_artifacts_dir() function is just here to take care of the ".../artifacts/uuid/" but it assume that "/var/log/validations" (or whatever path) already exists and is correct.


If the CI job doesn't grab the logs, it's because you replace:
".../artifacts/uuid"
by:
"../log/validations"
And the CI is expected to find an artifacts dir:
'/home/zuul/log/validations/169817bc-658d-4471-a895-d1dad8f13c58_check-cpu.yaml_2021-05-03T14:19:10.924418Z'

So we should keep the "../artifacts/" dir name, because it's Ansible datas and Ansible Runner needs it.

Imho, to address the issue of the log directory, it should be something outside of this function and, if it could be sharable with the callback "validation_json.py", it will be really great. Then validations-libs.something will return the correct path for the VF and the callback.
should be artifacts not log/validations.

You should drop this function, which doesn't really make sense.
If we want to check the presence of /tmp in the path, we dont need a specific function for it
s/folder."/folder. "/
s/volatile"/volatile "/
s/" location/"location/

s/valiations/validations/
s/fallback."/fallback. "/

If we assume that now the default directory for the log is:
$HOME/validations

then this function should just:
1/ check if this path is present
2/ if it's writable
3/ if not present try to create it.

You should revert to the master code here.
You are doing almost the same behavior.
this should be done in one place, only one time, otherwise you will get race where in some case it will fallback to tmp and some other not.
I think the missing part here is the check to see if the log_path provided by the caller is writable.

no log/validations but /validations/ right ?
and no more /tmp ?

No point in fixing docstrings until The thing actually works. Which might take a while.

But in general terms, most of this will have go.

and here, at this stage, we assume that the place where the "artifacts" directory will be created is sane and writable, so no need to check or default anything.

And mainly because, if this dir can not be created, the callback wont be able to write in the log path.

So every logic to check if log path is correct should happen before.

I suggest to revert to the original function for this part.

I think all of this could be simplified with the original function.
makedir is recursive, so if the VF is creating:
artifacrs/<uuid>
it will create both at the same time.
If artifacts already exists it will create only <uuid>.

The original function return as well the newly created directory and uuid, so no need to create a getter function there, since it's called and needed only 1 time.

Same for the marker, when we comes to the Ansible artifacts creation, we assume that the log directory is writable and accessible, so no need to ensure that at this stage.

I'm not an enemy of simplicity. And it is true, that amalgamation of these is possible.

But previous approach, albeit simple, also proved error prone and hard to debug.

We are not trying to accomplish a single task here, although it may seem to be the case.
The end result we seek, that is: writing validation ansible artifacts into a proper dir, along with logs one level above it, requires three steps to be taken.

1. Ensure we have logs dir to write to.
2. Ensure we have logs/artifacts dir to write to.
3. Generating uuid and ensuring we have logs/artifacts/<UUID>_something dir to write to.

All three are an IO operations, during which we can encounter various issues and which are, by definition, comparably slow.

The separation into several functions minimizes chance for confusion, by providing each with its own logging and exception handling. This way we can immediately recognize which is causing issues and proceed accordingly. 

Implementing all as single function would entail creation of several conditional check, increasing the complexity to a substantial degree.

Functions creating the actual directories were factored out in order to keep the try/except blocks simple and to minimize code repetition. For example the `_setup_artifacts_dir` contains code that would otherwise have to be duplicated. And placed once in the try, and again in the except clause. 

The get functions serve as, essentially, wrappers for the functions creating directories. Providing the exception handling on top.

Previously we were checking state of the logs/artifacts dir during each loop iteration, and in two different places, the utils.py and the constants.py. Now we only do it once, before entering the loop. And we do it only in utils.py, as the constants.py logic was removed. Making constants.py more like true constants.

The additional checks in all three of these steps, were implemented to precisely because the assumptions about filesystem don't have to hold. For example, the selected log dir may exist, but it may have wrong permissions. Only once we create the logs/artifacts dir can we be sure it's accessible to the current user.

I can combine the steps 1 and 2, but most of the functions really ought to stay. Otherwise we will return to previous problems. Only magnified, by us newly letting the user pick his log folder in the command line.

lib/neutron-legacy.message: I have an issue with the naming of it - it actually runs after they are started so it hardly configures them; it's for configuring the public bridge only...

I think this init is both redundant and a little dangerous.
In my setup, it causes the nb db to be recreated after neutron is running, causing a bunch of state (eg. pg_drop and default_ha_chassis_group) to be lost.

Turns out that calling init_ovn here can be problematic because it will delete the OVN databases [0]. 

Upon the Neutron service start the maintenance thread will create some resources (e.g the pg_drop port group and the default_ha_chassis_group HA Chassis Group) and, since this method is called later one it ends up getting rid of those because the DB files are deleted and recreated.

Thanks Flavio for spotting this in his local DevStack run.

I think we need to remove this line there, I don't think it's needed here anything because it's already invoked at [1] to get rid of the old files.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/96509ea025459ac077d2c85289da7725c53235cf/lib/neutron_plugins/ovn_agent#L592-L609
[1] https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/96509ea025459ac077d2c85289da7725c53235cf/lib/neutron-legacy#L476

One might think "which service needs to be enabled?". From what I read, it seems like ALL vim services must be enabled-active so <node>.vim_progress_status becomes "services-enabled".

Suggestion: "Application-apply required for stx-openstack, but some VIM services are not at enabled-active state on node controller-0. Application-apply rejected."

When vim_progress_status is 'services-disabled' on node, state from "system service-list" keeps at 'enabled-active' and will not be changed/impacted after node unlock.  It is vim_progress_status on host rather than 'enabled-active' to trigger application-apply.

You can also check sysinv audit which uses 'service-enabled' to trigger auto re-apply. You can also check metadata.yaml which uses 'availability: services-enabled'.

'enabled-active' is not used in this case.
vim_progress_status (e.g. 'services-enabled') is for VIM managed services; (as distinguished from SM managed services).

Just stating my reasoning behind asking for enabled-active in this message, if an operator see "services-disabled" on a host, he wouln't be able to know which service is not enabled. One will have to resort to "system service-list" and see which VIM services are NOT in "enabled-active" state, so "VIM services are not on enabled-active state".
We have vim_progress_status from 'system host-show controller-0'. There is no need to access "system service-list" after unlock the node.

Hello,

I think that we need to be cautious here (with threading).

When there's no active request, the worker process gets parked, so, it doesn't run the thread and we should start observing related issues with the metric collector.

When we don't use a native python thread then process become idle due to green thread/eventlet.
mod_wsgi and green thread aren't really compatible, it's just due to the way mod_wsgi handles processes.

Few years ago we experienced similar issues [1] with the rabbitmq heartbeat, and I think that here we are more or less in a similar context.

That can be easily fixed by using a python thread by default and all the time (e.g [2][3]).

I think that we need to follow the same path here and applying a native python thread to all the threads used here.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/22f240b82fffbd62be8568a7d0d3369134596ace
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/branch/master/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py#L49-L59
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/branch/master/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py#L992

Could be `conf.oslo_messaging_metrics` to refer directly on the local config and avoid inline references as below. However, the current version LGTM.

That could be addressed with a follow up.
Thanks! I updated this part, not sure if I understand your comment correctly. Can you check the newest patch?

If I understand correctly, you want to delete the oldest (count - max_backups) records. Unfortunately, you delete the newest ones. Because records in 'backup_items' are sorted by 'created_at' in  desc order(you can check again). That means backup_item[0] is the newest record, and backup_item[-1] is oldest one. backup_items[:count - max_backups] = [backup_items[0], .., backup_items[count - max_backups - 1]]. So the correct records are backup_items[max_backups:]. By the way, backup_items[x:y] will generate another new list, from the perspective of efficiency, it is better to visit the list by index, for example, 'for i in xrange(max_backups, count)'.
default_dir='desc', So backup_items[0] is the oldest one.

The checkpoint is deleted, but the corresponding 'checkpoint record' still in the DB. So, next time you will get that record again from DB, and delete it from 'bank'. Unfortunately, this time it must be failed, because it had been deleted. It is a design problem. So I advise you to discuss it on the IRC meeting.

'backup_items' are sorted by 'created_at' in  desc order. So it is better to visit 'backup_items' from tail to head, if one record does not exceed 'retention_duration', just break.

kubernetes/k8s-pod-recovery/centos/files.message: Do you know whether it's the fact that you have the --wait=false in the delete command that caused the subsequent wait command to return as condition=Ready?  I think this new change makes sense, and I think I like it better that we don't have to delete the device plugin pod if it's ready.  I'm just curious if it would have also worked with a timeout on the delete

Yes, the wait=false is causing that. The next command runs too quickly and returns before the pod status has changed to "Terminating"

The catch here is that removing the wait=false could cause the command to hang indefinitely.

I could also consider using the timeout flag for the delete command, but from the man page:
--timeout=0s: The length of time to wait before giving up on a delete, zero means determine a timeout from the
size of the object

It says it gives up on the delete when the timeout hits, which I don't think we want. So, this seems to be the safer approach.

neutron/db/l3_db.py.message: I need to consider the case where the segment has multiple subnets
is it possible that gw_port_segment will not be found in L1817-1821 and will be "None" here? If so, is that ok to have it set as None?

RPN allows to create networks with all subnets associated to segments or none of them; we cannot have some subnets associated to segments and not others in the same network. That means if the external network has subnets with segments, this logic will work.

In the case you present, if the subnet where the GW port IP is allocated does NOT have an associated segment, that means the other subnets are not associated neither. That means this is not a routed provider network and all subnets must be added as "extra_subnets".

I'll add a test case to cover this scenario.

NOTE: ^^ in "test__populate_ports_for_subnets_gw_port", I'll add "{'plugin_loaded': True, 'seg1': None, 'seg2': None}", that will check this scenario.

the code must be fixed because it breaks existing tests; as in test for the columns='b' fails because it does not start with uniq_ (line 144), but is mysql engine and tries to split it rendering 'b' into '' (line 149).

One solution to this can be to make adjustment on line 146

  if not columns.startswith(uniqbase) and "." + uniqbase not in columns

so that block is not executed as it is still contains uniq_ prefix.

Could also go with simple version 

  uniqbase not in columns

but this will fail if there is a column named, e.g., myuniq_columnname

In any case, have to think about the edge cases, because uniq_ can be part of the regular table and column name, and also identifiers can contain dots in mysql. Could add more tests for extreme edge cases, e.g., where table is `my.uniq_tablename` and column `my.uniq_columnname`, though such names containing dots and uniq_ should be near non-existing :)

to be consistent with other parts of this docstring, it should be `table_name.c1` and below `table_name.name_of_our_constraint`.

And probably there is still difference between mysqldb vs mysqlconnector, but then this is getting verbose.

Hi Greg,
 When you say "our recommendation is to use 2" you mean to say the second option CN=FQDN and SANs=FQDN ?

And to request a certificate(if requested through cert-manager), the cert request should be as follows with the options right?

option #1, CN=IPADDRESS and SANs=empty

apiVersion: cert-manager.io/v1alpha2
kind: Certificate
metadata:
  name: r-cert
  namespace: pvtest
spec:
  commonName: 2620:10a:a001:a103::1065
  duration: 43800h0m0s
  ipAddresses:
  - 2620:10a:a001:a103::1065
  - fd01:11::2
  issuerRef:
    kind: Issuer
    name: cloudplatform-interca-issuer
  organization:
  - CloudPlatform
  renewBefore: 360h

option #2 CN=FQDN and SANs=FQDN

apiVersion: cert-manager.io/v1alpha2
kind: Certificate
metadata:
  name: r-cert1
  namespace: pvtest
spec:
  commonName: cgcs-wolfpass-18-19.cumulus.wrs.com
  duration: 43800h0m0s
  ipAddresses:
  - 2620:10a:a001:a103::1065
  - fd01:11::2
  issuerRef:
    kind: Issuer
    name: cloudplatform-interca-issuer
  organization:
  - CloudPlatform
  renewBefore: 360h
  secretName: r-cert1

Yes, second option is the recommendation.

FQDN = Fully Qualified DNS Name ... so NOT an IP Address

So your examples would change to:



option #1, CN=IPADDRESS and SANs=empty

// ACTUALLY WITH CERT MANAGER IT WILL NOT LET YOU CREATE THIS CERTIFICATE WITH AN EMPTY SAN LIST ... I.E. at least one of dnsNames or ipAddresses is required.
// So you could only do this scenario with openssl commands.
// ... another reason why option 2 is better.

apiVersion: cert-manager.io/v1alpha2
kind: Certificate
metadata:

  name: r-cert
  namespace: pvtest
spec:
  commonName: 2620:10a:a001:a103::1065
  duration: 43800h0m0s
  issuerRef:
    kind: Issuer
    name: cloudplatform-interca-issuer
  organization:
  - CloudPlatform
  renewBefore: 360h
  secretName: r-cert



option #2 CN=FQDN and SANs=FQDN

  namespace: pvtest

  commonName: cgcs-wolfpass-18-19.cumulus.wrs.com
  duration: 43800h0m0s
  dnsNames:
  - cgcs-wolfpass-18-19.cumulus.wrs.com
  issuerRef:
    kind: Issuer
    name: cloudplatform-interca-issuer
  organization:
  - CloudPlatform
  renewBefore: 360h

doc/source/specs/stx-6.0/approved/os_200.message: nit: This shows up as "1 2" in the generated document - I have no idea why.

It is a bug in the generator as far as I can tell. I attempted to use symbols and had similar results. I am following the correct syntax as documented in the rst format. All the links are clickable and work.

There may also be a few kernel "issues" related to patches that CentOS is using, that are not part of upstream.  Such as the kernel timer lockless check, and possibly other changes around NOHZ mode.  These patches may have to be broken out of or otherwise gleaned from the CentOS source and maintained going forward as part of the StarlingX kernel patch set.  We may not even be aware of some of these patches until we observe different undesired behavior during testing.

This is somewhat covered in the section around performance and also touched on during my presentation at the PTG at the end of April (but in the context of userspace).

On the performance side there will need to be a testing period to ensure that individual use cases perform as expected and withing required metrics. If you know of any written requirements for metrics I will link them here but I was not able to find any.

Lacking specific requirements around performance we do want to avoid carrying technical debt in the kernel, so unless the CentOS kernel changes were backports (in which case moving to v5.10 should pick them up) we do want to be careful around which patches we add to the kernel.

As we get into implementation and testing we will definitely review the situation.
You mentioned above that there may be impacts to ansible and the installer - could mention that here too.

Should probably extend this to discuss testing for both the "standard" kernel and the low-latency kernel. Most of our kernel issues in recent times have been due to the low-latency patches so should call out that significant testing will be required there to ensure that none of the issues we hit (and fixed) with the CentOS kernel come back.

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/nest.message: perhaps 90 second is not the "right" timeout. Perhaps good approach is to take the same timeout as nova has for waiting for the port to become active before failing

Okay, so this is 300 seconds in Nova by default [1] and our RetryHandler times out after 500 seconds of wait. I think I'd rather make it lower than 300 seconds anyway. Note that in case of Nova it's not about subports being attached to trunk but regular ports plugged on the node. I guess we can expect more from Neutron. Plus subports will already sit a while in the pool in some cases.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/50fdbc752a9ca9c31488140ef2997ed59d861a41/nova/conf/compute.py#L160

is there a chance of "collision" due to making this 2 calls one after another? meaning different neutron server will handled the remove and add, and they won't be yet in sync and the add_subport fails due to "port already attached" or the like
Oh my, I don't know, do we really need to code around such deficiencies? I'll try asking Neutron folks.

Yes, I think that this can happen, looking at neutron server code, subport is created in https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/services/trunk/plugin.py#L358 and OVO's create() method will raise DuplicateSubPort exception in such case: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/objects/trunk.py#L80
That exception will be returned directly to the client as it's not handled anywhere in the neutron.
It seems that it might do that, yes.

Continuation of discussion on IRC [1] - Galera should not be out of sync between neutron-servers, so this is pretty implausible. I'm going to protect from this in another way - I'll ignore 404 on _remove_subport() to make sure that if _remove_subport() succeeded but _add_subport() failed we'll still have a way to recover from this once the KuryrPort is handled again.

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-neutron/%23openstack-neutron.2021-06-08.log.html#t2021-06-08T08:05:45
If _add_subport fail with an exception would it likely crash the controller and only then retry the event?
I guess I'll never stop making mistakes with words being homophones to me. ;)

Quick question: We still write the agent UUID [0] in the Chassis external_ids, right ? Otherwise how does the metadata shows up as an agent in the "agent list" command ?

[0] register_metadata_agent() from agent.py

Lucas, this is a great point. So far this patch is just taking care of the metadata readiness for the purpose of removing writes that are essential for the normal workflow.

A separate topic (I can add it to the commit message and/or rephrase the bullet point 2) is the healthchecks mechanism that, as you point out, would still write to the SB database. A follow-up patch would probably allow to enable/disable this mechanism but also operators can disable or ignore the health status of the agents in favor of scale/performance.

With this patch and, making agents to connect to the master SB database, you'll still get the healthcheck mechanism but you're reducing significantly the amount of events and writes to SB database, especially under scenarios where a lot of VMs are spawned/destroyed concurrently.

Let me know if this makes sense?
Ack

Yes, it makes sense. It's kinda how I imagine it would work. But, I would rephrase point 2) in the next patch-set. Reading it gives the impression that the agent no longer writes to the SB DB but, in reality, even tho we massively reduced the number of writes we still have a few happening.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm not sure I understand how this solves the problem. The new function also calls Keystone.

That said, if we implement the cache as suggested in [0] then this would benefit, so probably still a net benefit.

0: https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.limit/src/commit/efc26ae724d504ce3bdd5fc21b39a79fa93552a8/oslo_limit/limit.py#L243

Yeah, basically define the maximum amount of data we'd be willing to munch at the start, and even though that could change during a long-running activity where other things got deleted or added, it'd be reasonable. We could also use that value to bound when we check the quota again, in case you scrambled to delete stuff before you hit your quota or something. But anyway, you get the idea :)

It solves the problem because before we start a transfer, we can figure out what the current usage and quota is, calculate the different, and then stop the transfer later if we've munched more than that amount of data.

John's caching thing is definitely something we should have as well, just because we're banging the crap out of keystone in a lot of places. However, we'd really like to not have to pass an enforcer down into the deep depths of the data pipeline just so we can check to see if we've gone over the remaining limit. We'd opt for the slightly leaky quota enforcement over strict correctness in that case, obviously.
Ah, so the idea is to call this once before you start instead of repeatedly calling enforce in the inner loop. That makes sense.

what about cases where simple_crypto is not being used, and an alternate backend is in play?

I did try to handle this .. on l21, if the config section for [simple_crypto_plugin] is not present, or kek is not set, then $kek will be "", and the check on l23 will fail, so the script won't run.

If the kek is set (even if the simple_crypto backend isn't explicitly enabled in [crypto] enabled_crypto_plugins), then it the script will run, which I think is fair, since it is enabled by default.

It will only look for project keys that use the simple_crypto plugin, and if it doesn't find any, it will consider that a success.

Do you think there is a gap?

i know you are setting this to supress the old kek being output to stdout, but this approach will write it to a configmap (l26)/ It would be petter to inject this as an env var, or read from a secret if we are concerned about leaking the old kek.

barbican/templates/bin/_simple_crypto_ke.message: The decryption with the old KEK fails if the key is already wrapped with the new KEK. (This is fine, the nothing is changed in the database, and life goes on.) Is it worth explicitly checking for this?

What logging do want for the non-dry-run case?
I think just a log statement stating that the project-specific key has been re-wrapped with a master key.
Do we need better error handling? This is somewhat "best effort", which is probably ok - if we have a new KEK, and the old KEK doesn't work, there isn't much we can do about it.

Changed to "Project KEK" throughout when referring to project keys, and just KEK (or "global KEK") when talking about the master KEK.
